content: The "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" promotes the construction and operation of US flag cruise vessels in the country. It includes an amendment regarding coastwise transportation of passengers. The "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" promotes US flag cruise vessel construction and operation, with an amendment on coastwise passenger transportation requirements for vessels owned by US citizens or entities under specific laws. The Merchant Marine Act, 1920 requires vessels over 5 net tons to have a certificate of documentation under chapter 121 of title 46, US Code, with a coastwise endorsement. An exception is made for cruise vessels under a demise charter lasting at least 18 months to a person described in the Act. A cruise vessel under a demise charter can operate in coastwise trade for up to 6 months after the charter ends, with approval from the Secretary and compliance with specified terms. There is an exception for vessels to be reflagged. The Secretary may prescribe terms for approval of a cruise vessel under a demise charter for coastwise trade. An exception exists for vessels not documented under chapter 121 of title 46, U.S. Code, and at least 5 years old, to be reflagged. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 requires cruise vessels to be between 5 and 15 years old when documented under chapter 121 of title 46, U.S. Code. Owners must also have a contract for the construction of another cruise vessel with at least 80% capacity. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 mandates that cruise vessels must be between 5 and 15 years old when documented under chapter 121 of title 46, U.S. Code. Owners must also have a contract for the construction of another cruise vessel with at least 80% capacity. This requirement does not apply to a vessel after 18 months from the issuance of a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement if another vessel's keel has not been laid before the end of that period. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows for an extension of the 18-month period for laying the keel of a new vessel for up to 6 months. There are limitations on operations for persons who own or charter cruise vessels. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows for an extension of the 18-month period for laying the keel of a new vessel for up to 6 months. Limitations on operations for persons who own or charter cruise vessels include restrictions on operating between certain ports and islands, with penalties for violations. Penalties for violating the United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 include a $1,000 civil penalty per passenger transported in violation, seizure and forfeiture of the vessel for knowing violations, and disqualification from coastwise trade for those required to enter into construction contracts for cruise vessels. Those required to enter into construction contracts for cruise vessels may not own or operate any vessel in coastwise trade if construction milestones are not met. Coastwise trade includes passenger transportation within the United States or via a foreign port. The term 'coastwise trade' covers passenger transportation within the United States or through a foreign port. A 'cruise vessel' must be over 10,000 gross tons, have accommodations for 200 passengers, and not be a ferry. A 'related person' includes holding companies, subsidiaries, affiliates. The term 'related person' includes holding companies, subsidiaries, affiliates, officers, directors, and agents of a person or entity. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS. Section 3309 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to allow vessels meeting specific criteria to comply with certain subtitle regulations and receive a certificate of inspection from the Secretary. The criteria include meeting standards for control verification certificates for foreign vessels and obtaining a coastwise endorsement after a certain date. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows vessels with a coastwise endorsement issued after the enactment of the Act to engage in coastwise trade. The authorization is granted under specific provisions of the Act approved in 1886. SEC. 5. CITIZENSHIP FOR PURPOSES OF DOCUMENTATION. Section 2 of the Shipping Act, 1916 is amended to include new provisions regarding determining citizenship for vessels primarily transporting passengers in coastwise trade. Ownership of vessels in coastwise trade must be majority owned by US citizens, free from any foreign trust or obligations. Amendment to Title XI of the Merchant Marine Act, 1936 includes changes to Section 1101(b) regarding passenger and cargo. Permits for vessels entering units of the National Park System are also addressed. The Secretary of the Interior has priority in permitting vessel operations in the National Park System. Priority is given to vessels documented in the US or with rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. The Secretary of the Interior has priority in permitting vessel operations in the National Park System, with priority given to vessels documented in the US or with rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. Any person operating a vessel in the unit must comply with section 1307(a) of the Act, including vessels documented under foreign laws. The Secretary may revoke or refuse to renew permission for foreign-documented vessels. The Secretary of the Interior can revoke or refuse to renew permission for foreign-documented vessels operating in a unit of the National Park System if a person requests permission for a US-documented vessel and there is a limit on permits. The Secretary of the Interior cannot revoke or refuse to renew permission for visitor services in a National Park if the person holds rights under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. If permission is revoked, the person has the right of first refusal for a new permit in that National Park unit. The right of first refusal for a permit to provide visitor services in a National Park unit is granted when conditions no longer apply, limited to revoked or not renewed permits.
